Award.AwardTitle: Establishing a Distributed Community of Educators To study a transformational education experiment

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This engineering education research project seeks to create and evaluate a trans-disciplinary learning environment that has been shown to be effective for engineers in order to build skills in leadership and reflective judgment. To create this environment the PIs plan to create an observation network for their learning environment that will serve as a model to engage a broad spectrum of stakeholders: educational practitioners, researchers, business interests, governmental representatives, and non-profit organizations. If successful, this project can serve as a model that could inform the practice of education through establishing a mechanism for rapid feedback of observation back to the classroom.

The broader significance and importance of this project is to provide a model that better integrates educational practice with educational research. The project uses a set of transdisciplinary courses that link engineering practice to larger societal concerns as the test-bed for the proposed observation network. Such courses have been shown to attract and retain under-represented students. The overall impact of the proposed work will, if successful, be to provide a model for tighter collaboration between those who research engineering education and those who apply research in the classroom.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was asking the question, "What is the process of radical educational innovation in engineering at institutions that are optimized for something else?" The goal was to demonstrate a transformational path for systemic change in higher education in general and engineering education in particular.  We were focused on the faculty members as agents of change. What we discovered was that transformational change - the kind of change where people make conscious choices that are outside of their habits - is favored when certain conditions are in place. The conditions include a social setting that: favors a "default mode" neurological state (often called a "relaxed state"); represents a sufficient diversity of views about the nature of reality;and contains a shared commitment to an outcome that transcends personal interests. 

We concluded that the well-known tendency for the engineering education system to resist change is an unintended consequence of our shared mental models. A common example of a shared belief is captured in the phrase, "Survival of the fittest," which is often misconstrued to mean that the strongest survives. We note that many disciplines have this same dynamic with the same problematic unintended consequences: the elimination of diversity in all its forms. This tendency to eliminate diversity is hidden in the unexamined and shared interest in "economy of scale."

Our findings point to the need to develop a new type of science, which we call the "science of emergence."  This new science would account for the dynamic complexity of a system. Such a system contains a recursive interaction and interconnectivity amongst the system's components. One can think of any educational learning environment as a dynamically complex system where the social and political "forces" create changes within the biology of the learner.

A science of complexity would focus on creating the conditions that foster the spontaneous emergence of the desired result from the whole of the system. The reason that this new science needs to be developed is because the natural world is a complex, dynamic system. Most physical scientific knowledge is based on simple systems that are not in flux and can be controlled to produce predictable outcomes. These ways of manipulating matter have worked well for inanimate objects but have considerable negative consequences when applied to humans. This new science would apply not only to learning environments but to constructively working with the natural world. 

We have connected our findings of transformation conditions in learning environments to some recent neuroscience findings.  Others have established that "knowledge" is embodied, literally in clusters of neuron nodes distributed throughout the human body and connected to what we think of as "cognition" through language. 

Our work also points to the possibility that transformational innovation that emerges from a group can be favored through collective practices that involved neurological changes in the body. The theory is that the embodied neurology contains historically-developed "responses," so practices that allow a greater facility or a "holistic neurological intelligence" or equivalently, a "whole body intelligence," could allow for the possibility of responses outside of the historical responses.
